content.text: Giants (8-8) at Eagles (10-6)  4:30 p.m., Ch. 5  EAGLES' BRIAN WESTBROOK VS. GIANTS' TIKI BARBER  Tiki Barber (1,662 yards rushing, 465 receiving) and Brian Westbrook (1,217 and 699) finished fifth and sixth in the N.F.L. in yards from scrimmage. They are small and versatile backs, and whoever has the better game will most likely be headed to the next round of the playoffs -- unless they cancel each other out, as they have done twice this season. The Eagles have the 26th-ranked rush defense, but held Barber to 126 yards on 40 carries in two meetings. The Giants, under their new play-caller, Kevin Gilbride, have vowed to be more committed to the run. While Eli Manning has played relatively well against the Eagles, and quarterback Jeff Garcia has sparked the Eagles' five-game winning streak, each team would like to put its chances in the hands of its ball carriers.  BY THE NUMBERS, GIANTS vs. EAGLES  3.15  Average gain per rush by Giants running back Tiki Barber in two games against the Eagles. In 14 other games, Barber averaged 5.4 yards a carry.  8  Sacks of Giants quarterback Eli Manning by the Eagles on Sept. 17. He was not sacked more than twice in any other game, including the Dec. 17 rematch, when he was sacked once.  23  Points scored by the Giants in the fourth quarter and overtime on Sept. 17 to overcome a 24-7 fourth-quarter deficit.  22  Points scored by the Eagles in the fourth quarter on Dec. 17, leading to a 36-22 victory.  QUOTABLE  ''We expected to be here. Yeah, we didn't get here the way that we wanted to, but we're here.''  Giants running back Tiki Barber, on making the playoffs.  JOHN BRANCH  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: KEY MATCHUP

content.text: The Mets signed the journeyman catcher Mike DiFelice to a minor league contract yesterday. DiFelice, 37, was added to the Mets' major league roster in August when the backup catcher Ramon Castro went on the disabled list because of a sore left rib cage. In 15 games with the Mets, DiFelice batted .080. Castro returned for the playoffs, and DiFelice was left off the postseason roster.  MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT  SPORTS BRIEFING: BASEBALL
content.title: MINOR LEAGUE DEAL FOR DIFELICE

content.text: Patriots Put a Stop to the Titans' Run  Corey Dillon ran for two touchdowns and Tom Brady threw for one as the Patriots defeated the Titans, 40-23, dashing Tennessee's hopes for a playoff spot. The host Titans (8-8) had won six games in a row and needed to beat the Patriots and hope the Jaguars, Bengals and Broncos lost. All three did, but the Titans proved no match for the Patriots (12-4), who will play the Jets in a wild-card game Sunday.  With New Orleans (10-6) set to play host to its first playoff game in the rebuilt Superdome in two weeks, Coach Sean Payton removed several key players early in the Saints' 31-21 loss to the visiting Panthers. Quarterback Drew Brees played only one full series and was 4 of 5 for 46 yards. Reggie Bush rushed for an early touchdown but played little more than a quarter, and running back Deuce McAllister had the day off. Carolina finished 8-8.  Shaun Alexander rushed for 92 yards and scored on a 1-yard run in the first quarter as the Seahawks defeated the Buccaneers, 23-7. Visiting Seattle (9-7) had little to play for after clinching the National Football Conference West title; they will play host to Dallas in the first round Saturday. Tampa Bay finished 4-12.  Chargers and Ravens Finish 1-2 in A.F.C.  Philip Rivers threw two touchdown passes after spraining his right foot, and LaDainian Tomlinson also limped off after wrapping up his first rushing title as the Chargers defeated the visiting Cardinals, 27-20. The Chargers (14-2), who have won 10 in a row, clinched home-field advantage throughout the American Football Conference playoffs. Rivers and Tomlinson, who had one of his legs stepped on, said they would have played if the result had been more important, but the Chargers had already earned a first-round bye. Tomlinson ran for 66 yards, giving him 1,815 this season. Arizona finished 5-11.  Using a stellar performance from the defense and an efficient effort from the offense, the Ravens beat the Bills, 19-7, to earn the No. 2 seeding in the A.F.C. Chris McAlister returned an interception 31 yards for a touchdown and the host Ravens (13-3) allowed only 39 yards rushing. Buffalo finished 7-9.  Colts Finish Strong, but Cowboys Do Not  Peyton Manning threw two touchdown passes and ran for another score as the Colts held on to beat the visiting Dolphins, 27-22. Manning's two scoring passes gave him 275 in his career, moving him ahead of Joe Montana into seventh on the career list. Indianapolis (12-4), which blew a chance to earn a first-round bye by losing four times in the previous six weeks, will play host to Kansas City in a wild-card game Saturday. Cleo Lemon was solid in his first N.F.L. start for Miami (6-10), finishing 18 of 36 for 210 yards.  Done in by repeated mistakes from quarterback Tony Romo and a few more by cornerback Terence Newman, the Cowboys lost To the visiting Lions, 39-31, and blew their chance to stay alive in the N.F.C. East race. ''I can't tell you how disappointed I am, I really can't,'' Cowboys Coach Bill Parcells said. As much as Dallas (9-7) wanted to win the game, Detroit (3-13) might have been better off losing it. By winning, they gave the Raiders the No. 1 overall pick in the draft. But even the Lions could not refuse the gifts the Cowboys gave them, from a penalty on Newman that wiped out an interception return for a touchdown on the game's first snap to Romo's two fumbles and an interception.  In Other Games  Steven Jackson had a career-high 4 touchdowns and 142 yards rushing, helping the visiting Rams defeat the Vikings, 41-21. Jackson's 59-yard touchdown run in the fourth quarter prevented Minnesota (6-10) from establishing a postmerger N.F.L. record for fewest yards rushing allowed in a season. They missed by 15 the mark of 970 yards set by the Ravens in 2000. The Rams finished 8-8.  Despite losing running back Ron Dayne (ankle) and tight end Jeb Putzier (broken foot) to injuries in pregame warm-ups, the Texans defeated the visiting Browns, 14-6. Houston (6-10) won back-to-back games for the first time since 2004 and tripled its victory total from last season. Cleveland finished 4-12.  PRO FOOTBALL

content.text: Before the Knicks' game on Wednesday night, they vowed that Gilbert Arenas would not beat them with his scoring. He did not. He beat them by not taking the game-winning shot.  The Knicks were so concerned about stopping Arenas at the end of a tight game that they left Caron Butler open underneath the basket for a dunk that gave the Wizards a 99-98 victory at the Verizon Center.  ''It's obviously frustrating,'' Quentin Richardson said. ''You never want to lose that way. At the same time, we denied, denied and swarmed. They just made a great play at the end. They found probably the only open guy on the court.''  Coach Isiah Thomas was also dejected. He fielded a few questions from the news media before leaving the arena with a sour look on his face.  Arenas scored 16 points in what was a quiet night for him. He entered the game averaging 30.2 points, second most in the N.B.A, and he was coming off a 51-point performance against the Utah Jazz on Monday, when he made a game-winning 3-pointer.  Stephon Marbury deserved ample credit for his defense of Arenas, who made 4 of 14 shots and went 0 for 5 from beyond the 3-point arc. A double team -- and sometimes even a triple team -- never seemed far away when the ball arrived in Arenas's hands.  ''I've never really tried to beat double teams like that, because I know what kind of energy it takes to do that,'' Arenas said. ''I had to do that all through high school.''  Marbury has been playing exceptionally well on defense in recent weeks, which has sparked the Knicks (17-23) to four wins in their last six games.  ''I always play defense,'' Marbury said. ''I don't get enough credit for playing defense. I think this year it's just being talked about more because Isiah spoke about it and he said that I was playing the best defense of my career.''  The Knicks led twice in the closing moments. Marbury made a driving layup over Antawn Jamison to give the Knicks their first lead of the second half, 96-95, with 31 seconds left. After Jamison made a layup, the Knicks went to Jamal Crawford, who made the game-winning shot on Monday against the Sacramento Kings.  Crawford delivered again, making a runner in the lane after driving past Jamison. That gave the Knicks a 98-97 lead with 12.4 seconds left.  After a timeout, the Wizards (22-16) inbounded the ball to Arenas, and most of the 16,503 fans probably thought he would take the final shot. Arenas also made a game-winning 3-pointer against the Milwaukee Bucks earlier this month.  The Knicks closed in, as they had the entire game. Arenas passed to Jamison, who drove toward the basket before dishing off to DeShawn Stevenson on the left wing. Eddy Curry went out to cover Stevenson, who passed underneath to Butler.  ''That wasn't an easy pass that he made, but he got it through there,'' Curry said. ''You got to give him credit.''  Butler dunked with one hand to quash the Knicks' hopes of a thrilling comeback.  Crawford's desperation shot from near midcourt was on target but fell just short at the final buzzer.  ''We played a hard-fought game,'' Richardson said. ''We went blow for blow with them. Unfortunately they just got the last punch.''  The loss spoiled a fine offensive performance by Richardson, who finished with a game-high 35 points and made seven 3-pointers. He had 25 points in the first half.  The game was close for most of the first half, but the Wizards took a 14-point lead in the third quarter, when they went on a 19-3 spurt.  The Wizards led, 81-70, to start the fourth quarter, but the Knicks scored 8 consecutive points to cut the lead to 81-78.  They kept chipping away by going to Curry in the paint and threatening with Richardson from the perimeter. When Richardson made a 3-pointer with 2 minutes 45 seconds remaining, the Knicks cut the lead to 93-92.  With Arenas quiet, the Wizards went to Butler and Jamison. Butler led them with 27 points and Jamison added 21.  ''Everybody in the league, despite what anybody else says or writes, knows those two can play,'' Richardson said. ''But obviously Gilbert is the focal point.''  Last night it became apparent early on that he would not be the focal point. In the first quarter, Arenas mostly stood at the top of the key as his teammates looked for an open man. He took only 3 of the Wizards' first 17 shots.  ''We all knew what they were going to do before, and that's why we tried to keep four shooters out there when I was in,'' Arenas said.  Arenas began to look for his shot in the final minutes of the opening quarter. He finally got going when the Knicks handed him four consecutive free throws.  Thomas and Marbury were hit with technical fouls after arguing after Marbury was whistled for a touch foul as Arenas was shooting. He missed the shot but he made both technical free throws and both free throws that resulted from the initial foul.  Arenas was quiet for nearly the rest of the game, but just the threat of his scoring did the Knicks in.  ''We gave ourselves a chance to win,'' Jared Jeffries said. ''That's all you can really ask for.''  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Neutralizing Arenas Not Enough for Knicks

content.text: AMERICAN FOOTBALL CONFERENCE  SEEDING --1  TEAM -- San Diego Chargers (West champions)  The Chargers have won 10 in a row, including the finale over Arizona to clinch home-field advantage throughout the A.F.C. playoffs. If the seedings hold up, their first game could be a doozy: against New England, whose coach, Bill Belichick, would surely try to confuse quarterback Philip Rivers in his first playoff game, and whose solid run defense would give LaDainian Tomlinson one of his biggest challenges of the season.  RECORD -- 14-2  1ST-ROUND OPPONENT -- BYE  SEEDING -- 2  TEAM -- Baltimore Ravens (North champions)  Baltimore beat Buffalo yesterday, using its fifth interception return for a touchdown to secure the second seeding and a first-round bye. The Ravens have won four in a row and their offense has been energized since Brian Billick took over the play-calling. But a run in the playoffs will still be all about their top-rated defense. Baltimore held the Chargers to 13 points in October to hand San Diego its first loss.  RECORD --13-3  1ST-ROUND OPPONENT -- BYE  SEEDING -- 3  TEAM -- Indianapolis Colts (South champions)  The Colts held off the Dolphins yesterday to secure the third seeding, but the Dolphins, playing a meaningless game, moved down the field with ease late in the fourth quarter, a bad omen for Indianapolis. The defense is not as good as it was last year, and the Colts will go only as far as their porous run defense - the worst in the league - allows them. The Chiefs have a star running back in Larry Johnson, and that could mean another early exit for the Colts.  RECORD -- 12-4  1ST-ROUND OPPONENT -- Kansas City  SEEDING -- 4  TEAM -- New England Patriots (East champions)  After an erratic season, the Patriots go into the playoffs on a roll after pounding Vince Young (five sacks, three turnovers) and the Titans yesterday. They remain an intimidating playoff opponent because of Tom Brady, who has had a superb season despite a dearth of receiver talent. But the Jets held the Patriots to 14 points in Foxborough in November.  RECORD -- 12-4  1ST-ROUND OPPONENT -- Jets  SEEDING -- 5  TEAM -- Jets  The Jets defeated the Raiders yesterday to secure a wild-card spot, completing a remarkable rookie regular season for Coach Eric Mangini, who took over a team that won only four games last season. The Jets started looking like a serious threat when they beat the Patriots in Foxborough in mid-November. Now they are going back for another visit, another chance for Bill Belichick to offer Mangini a warm welcome back.  RECORD -- 10-6  1ST-ROUND OPPONENT -- New England  SEEDING -- 6  TEAM -- Kansas City Chiefs  The Chiefs snuck in when the Broncos lost to the 49ers in overtime yesterday and Pittsburgh beat Cincinnati. The Chiefs survived Trent Green's severe concussion in the season opener because they leaned heavily on running back Larry Johnson. Coach Herman Edwards will no doubt do that again when he faces his friend Tony Dungy's suspect run defense.  RECORD -- 9-7  1ST-ROUND OPPONENT -- Indianapolis  NATIONAL FOOTBALL CONFERENCE  SEEDING -- 1  TEAM -- Chicago Bears (North champions)  The Bears wrapped up the top seeding long ago on the strength of their dominating defense, rendering last night's game against the Packers meaningless. But the Bears still have not answered the biggest question about a potential run to the Super Bowl: What happens if quarterback Rex Grossman struggles? It is a question that could shape the postseason for the N.F.C., especially if the Bears face the Saints, who have a top-five pass defense, in the conference championship game.  RECORD -- 13-3  1ST-ROUND OPPONENT -- BYE  SEEDING -- 2  TEAM -- New Orleans Saints (South champions)  The Saints, the feel-good story of the season, may also be the most dangerous team in the N.F.C., and after their decimation of the Giants in Week 15, everyone knows it. Drew Brees, Reggie Bush and Deuce McAllister rested for most of the Saints' meaningless loss to the Panthers yesterday. Bush versus Chicago linebacker Brian Urlacher in the conference championship would be a blockbuster.  RECORD -- 10-6  1ST-ROUND OPPONENT -- BYE  SEEDING -- 3  TEAM -- Philadelphia Eagles (East champions)  The Eagles finished the season with five consecutive victories behind the backup quarterback Jeff Garcia, who has been so effective leading a balanced offense that Donovan McNabb's mother is worried about her injured son's future. The Eagles defeated the Giants, 36-22, just two weeks ago, and they seem to be getting stronger and more confident by the week. Their offense, improbably, is in the top five in the league.  RECORD -- 10-6  1ST-ROUND OPPONENT -- Giants  SEEDING -- 4  TEAM -- Seattle Seahawks (West champions)  The Seahawks blew out the Buccaneers in their season finale, but they had lost three in a row before that. They are nowhere near the powerhouse team that went to the Super Bowl last season. And the final game was costly: Cornerback Kelly Herndon broke his left ankle (another cornerback, Marcus Trufant, didn't play because of a sprained ankle) and linebacker Leroy Hill sustained a concussion.  RECORD -- 9-7  1ST-ROUND OPPONENT -- Dallas  SEEDING -- 5  TEAM -- Dallas Cowboys  Less than a month ago, the Cowboys had a two-game lead in the N.F.C. East and looked like the best team in the conference. But yesterday, with a chance to win the division, they lost to the Lions at home, their third loss in their final four games. Quarterback Tony Romo was voted into the Pro Bowl, but he has struggled in those three losses. Seattle's Qwest Field is one of the loudest, most difficult stadiums in the league. Seattle's secondary is injury-riddled, so the complaining Dallas receivers should get plenty of action.  RECORD -- 9-7  1ST-ROUND OPPONENT -- Seattle  SEEDING -- 6  TEAM -- Giants  The Giants survived a near-complete collapse and rediscovered their offense to sneak into the playoffs with almost no momentum. They played the Eagles close for a while two weeks ago, but their defense was gashed up the middle by the Eagles' rushers. Earlier in the season, the Giants forged an epic comeback to beat the Eagles in Philadelphia. But that was a long time ago, and if they beat the Eagles next week, it will be an even greater comeback for the season.  RECORD -- 8-8  1ST-ROUND OPPONENT -- Philadelphia  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: Looking Ahead to the Playoffs

content.text: For now, Seton Hall looks like the best Big East basketball team from the state of New Jersey. For the Pirates, that may be as good as it gets the rest of this season.  In front of a small crowd (7,214) at Continental Arena that included an impartial Gov. Jon S. Corzine, Seton Hall defeated interstate rival Rutgers, 77-72, Wednesday night.  The game kicked off the Big East portion of the schedule for Seton Hall and Rutgers, which figures to mean problems for both. Neither team fared particularly well in the nonconference portion of their schedules and must now play much tougher opponents.  Both have first-year coaches and are in a rebuilding mode. Bobby Gonzalez has come over from Manhattan to try to get Seton Hall (9-4, 1-0) back on track. Fred Hill is the new coach at Rutgers (7-7, 0-1).  So far, it is Gonzalez's team that seems to be on the faster track.  ''We don't know how long we are going to stay undefeated in the league, but the bottom line is that we're 9-4 and we won our first Big East game, and it's a rivalry game,'' Gonzalez said. ''Rivalry games are important. We've got to find ways to win games and scratch and claw. That's what we did. That's what we're going to have to do every game. No games this year are going to be easy for us.''  The Pirates have a talented freshman, Eugene Harvey, they can build around. A point guard, he had 21 points for Seton Hall on Wednesday. Brian Laing also had 21.  ''Eugene Harvey makes everyone else on the floor better,'' Hill said. ''Everybody gets worried about Eugene's penetration and that opens up the floor for Laing and Jamar Nutter. He's their catalyst and he makes them go. The better Eugene plays and as he continues to develop and grow, they will develop and grow as a team.''  It appeared early on that Seton Hall was going to run away with the game. The Pirates had a 34-16 lead with 5 minutes 17 seconds to go in the first half.  But the Scarlet Knights went on a 17-0 run to cut the Pirates' lead to 34-33. Rutgers had its first lead, 54-53, on a hook shot by J. R. Inman with 10:11 to go. Seton Hall then started to take control. When Harvey scored on a driving layup with 4:44 to play, the Pirates had a 68-61 lead.  Rutgers was not done. When Hamaday N'Diaye dunked with 1:07 left to go, the Seton Hall lead was down to 68-66. Making 9 of 10 free-throw attempts inside the final minute, Seton Hall was able to close out the game.  Rutgers was led by Inman, who had 18 points and 12 rebounds.  ST. JOHN'S 64, DEPAUL 53 -- Aaron Spears, playing for the first time since serving a four-game suspension, scored all 6 of his points in the final nine and a half minutes and St. John's won a Big East opener at Madison Square Garden.  Daryll Hill, who has battled a knee injury all season, had 9 points for the Red Storm (10-4), including a 3-pointer from deep in the corner as the shot clock ran out for a 59-52 lead with 45 seconds to play.  Wilson Chandler had 15 points for the Blue Demons (9-6).  Hill, who came in averaging 6.5 points a game, and Spears, who was averaging 2.8, combined to score 12 straight points for the Red Storm in the second half.(AP)  NOTRE DAME 78, LOUISVILLE 62 -- Tory Jackson, a freshman point guard, tied a career high with 14 points to help 17th-ranked Notre Dame beat visiting Louisville in a Big East opener. Jackson was put in the starting lineup after Kyle McAlarney was arrested on a marijuana possession charge last week and suspended indefinitely.  Notre Dame (13-1) has won 12 consecutive games for the first time in nearly 33 years. Terrence Williams led Louisville (10-5) with 18 points, but the Cardinals continued to struggle offensively. (AP)  NORTH CAROLINA 102, PENNSYLVANIA 64 -- Tyler Hansbrough and Reyshawn Terry scored 19 points apiece, and No. 2 North Carolina routed visiting Pennsylvania for its 10th straight victory. Wayne Ellington added 17 points for North Carolina (13-1), which used a 27-4 run late in the first half to take command against the Quakers (6-6). (AP)  WEST VIRGINIA 67, VILLANOVA 56 -- Frank Young scored a career-high 25 points, including eight 3-pointers, for No. 25 West Virginia (12-1, 2-0) in a Big East game. Curtis Sumpter, conference's second-leading scorer, led visiting Villanova (10-3, 0-1) with 21 points. (AP)  GEORGE WASHINGTON 70, FORDHAM 59 -- Maureece Rice had 17 points and 6 rebounds to lead George Washington (9-3) past visiting Fordham in the Atlantic 10 opener for both teams. Marcus Stout had 15 points for Fordham (7-6) to give him 1,001 in his career. (AP)  IN OTHER GAMES -- Dan Nwaelele led a balanced offense with 22 points, and No. 20 Air Force (14-1, 1-0 Mountain West Conference) beat Colorado State, 81-75, for its 10th straight victory.  Cliff Hammonds's layup with three seconds left lifted No. 23 Clemson (15-0) past Florida State, 68-66, in the Atlantic Coast Conference opener for both teams. (AP)  WOMEN  MARYLAND 80, NORTH CAROLINA STATE 61 -- Top-ranked Maryland (16-0) opened Atlantic Coast Conference play in the same fashion it handled the nonleague portion of its schedule: with a blowout victory. Laura Harper scored 17 points and Coach Brenda Frese earned her 100th win at Maryland.  Shay Doron scored 10 points to move into second place on the Terps' career scoring list. Doron, a senior guard, has 1,681 points. (AP)  DUKE 72, MIAMI 42 -- Carrem Gay had 12 points and 10 rebounds to lead third-ranked Duke (15-0) past Miami in the A.C.C. (AP)  TENNESSEE 72, ALABAMA 36 -- In a Southeastern Conference opener, Candace Parker scored 15 points and No. 4 Tennessee (13-1) beat visiting Alabama (10-6) for the 31st consecutive time. (AP)  COLLEGE BASKETBALL: ROUNDUP
content.title: Seton Hall Starts Big East Play On Right Track, Beating Rutgers

Connecticut lost for the fifth time in seven games, falling to visiting Indiana.  COVERAGE, PAGE 5  COLLEGE HIGHLIGHTS

content.text: The Nets squandered double-digit leads in the fourth quarter and lost each of their first two games of their trip out West, a reflection of their inability to maintain a steady course this season.  The letdowns, 1-point defeats to the Sacramento Kings on Monday night and the Golden State Warriors on Wednesday night, came on the heels of a four-game winning streak that had the Nets at .500 for the first time in two months. They have followed each apparent turning point this season with a misstep.  With their season past the midway point, the Nets (20-22) were still trying for their first road victory against a Western Conference opponent when they played the Los Angeles Clippers (20-21) on Thursday night.  After the game against the Warriors, ''the mood was not good,'' Rod Thorn, the Nets' president, said Thursday morning. ''If you're a competitor, as a player or as a coach, you're very upset about that, about losing two games like that, games that you had in hand.''  Perhaps most disheartening for the Nets is that their five-game trip was getting more difficult. They play the Denver Nuggets on Saturday night and the Utah Jazz on Monday.  ''Virtually every game, we're playing a better team,'' Thorn said. ''We've got our work cut out for us.''  Against the Kings, the Nets held a 20-point lead in the third quarter, only to have it evaporate at the hands of Sacramento point guard Mike Bibby, who capped a strong fourth quarter by making the winning shot with 10 seconds remaining.  ''We just quit playing,'' Thorn said. ''We just stood around in the fourth quarter.''  The Nets led the Warriors by 11 points with a little more than four minutes remaining, but Golden State finished the game on a 17-5 run, capped by guard Monta Ellis hitting the winner at the buzzer. It was the seventh time this season the Nets had lost after squandering a double-digit lead.  ''It is hard,'' Nets forward Bostjan Nachbar said after the game. ''It is not easy. We had both games won. We thought we were the better team, at least most of the game. We lost the game down the stretch, and the next couple games will show how tough we are.''  The Nets' grit will have to start with their two stars, Jason Kidd and Vince Carter. That is especially true with their third top-flight player, Richard Jefferson, out for about six weeks after he had arthroscopic surgery on his right ankle Monday.  Kidd has been stellar all season, playing some of the best basketball of his career, but he had eight turnovers against the Warriors.  Carter, after leading by 214,000 votes the last time they were counted, was surpassed in the All-Star voting by the Washington Wizards' Gilbert Arenas for an Eastern Conference starting spot Thursday. Arenas beat out Carter by 3,010 votes, the smallest margin in 17 years. Carter has been voted a starter six times.  Before Thursday night's game, Carter pretended to have thought he had beaten out Arenas. After sarcastically acting as if his feelings were hurt, Carter said he would not be disappointed to go the game as a reserve.  ''It's still an honor to be involved in it,'' he said.  For now, Carter has more pressing things to think about. He scored only 8 points against the Kings. Despite having 23 points and a career-high 13 assists against the Warriors, he did not dominate down the stretch.  The injuries to Jefferson and center Nenad Krstic, who is out for the season with a torn anterior cruciate ligament, have probably affected Carter more than any other player because he faces more double-teams.  As the Nets have struggled this season, Carter has seemed to be the most likely candidate for a trade if Thorn chooses to make drastic changes. Carter can opt out of his contract at the end of the season, meaning the Nets may try to get someone in return for him if they feel he may leave.  But with the Nets' recent success -- they had won 9 of 11 games before losing to the Kings and the Warriors -- much of the trade talk seemed to have settled.  The Nets' ability to make any significant trades by the Feb. 22 deadline could be hampered by the fact that two of their biggest assets, Jefferson and Krstic, are injured.  ''When you're talking about trading, you trade from assets,'' Thorn said. ''If you don't have a lot of assets to trade, it's difficult to make anything but a minor trade.''  BASKETBALL
content.title: Nets Take Two Steps Back After a Big Step Forward

content.text: A young, rebuilding Rutgers team might have learned something Wednesday night. It probably is not going to win a jump-shooting contest.  Against the Syracuse zone defense, Rutgers could do little else but shoot long-range jumpers, a strategy that failed. Hitting 18 of 61 shots (29.5 percent) from the field and scoring just 20 points in the paint, the Scarlet Knights were no match for Syracuse, losing by 68-58.  Only the reserve guard Courtney Nelson, who led Rutgers with 14 points, seemed to be in any rhythm for the Scarlet Knights (8-8, 1-2 Big East). But he made only 3 of 9 field-goal attempts.  ''I thought we did a good job of getting the ball inside, but, of course, any time you see a zone you've got to make shots,'' Rutgers Coach Fred Hill said. ''There are a lot of different ways to attack a zone, but you've got to make shots to loosen things up a bit. We got some great looks, but they didn't go down.''  The Orange (13-4, 2-1 Big East) offered a far more diverse attack. Shooting 46.9 percent, they got solid interior play from Darryl Watkins (9 points, 10 rebounds) and Demetris Nichols (12 points, 7 rebounds), as well as good perimeter shooting from guard Eric Devendorf, who led all scorers with 19 points.  ''These games are made for Eric,'' Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim said. ''Teams will go way out with their defense. That creates space for him to get to the basket.''  The Orange also helped itself at the free-throw line, making 18 of 21 attempts.  Rutgers was cold throughout, making 9 of 32 field-goal attempts during an opening half that ended with Syracuse leading, 28-25. Ten Syracuse turnovers helped Rutgers stay close.  The Orange got an immediate lift from an unlikely source. Guard Andy Rautins, who was averaging 5 points a game, scored 9 of Syracuse's first 11 points. He did not score again.  Syracuse took control early in the second half. A dunk by Nichols with 16 minutes 4 seconds left extended the lead to 39-30, and for Rutgers, it would only get worse. When Roberts dunked with 4:55 to go, the Orange had a 60-43 lead. Rutgers cut the deficit in the closing minutes, and when Marquis Webb scored on a putback with 54.4 seconds left, the lead was 6 points. Nichols responded by making a pair of free throws, and seconds later, Devendorf sealed the game by making two more free throws.  ''The shots weren't falling,'' Rutgers forward J. R. Inman said. ''It just wasn't outside. We were missing midrange and a lot of shots we usually hit. It was an adjustment for us. We haven't played a team that big down low. When you see a zone and with a lot of big, athletic guys, it's hard to adjust.''  The loss came just four days after Rutgers played what might have been its best game of the season, a 54-42 victory at Cincinnati. The 42 points were the fewest scored against Rutgers by a Big East opponent.  The Orange have beaten Rutgers six straight times, which includes an 86-84 overtime victory last season at the Carrier Dome. Three of Syracuse's four losses have come against teams that were ranked at the time.  COLLEGE BASKETBALL
content.title: Rutgers Can't Get Shots to Drop Against Tough Syracuse Defense

content.text: Everything the Nets would like to be was wrapped into their 116-115 victory over the Utah Jazz on Monday night.  A team with a dominant star player: Vince Carter scored 33 points, including the winning 3-pointer at the buzzer.  A team with a balanced supporting cast: Eddie House had 19 points, and Antoine Wright and Marcus Williams added 12 each.  A team with resiliency: the Nets fought their way back from 13 points down in the second quarter and from 4 down with less than a minute and a half to play.  And then there was the performance of Jason Kidd, the face of the franchise, who had 22 points, 10 assists and 6 rebounds.  The Nets displayed those characteristics throughout their five-game Western trip, even if they finished with a 2-3 record. Perhaps that is why they seemed to be feeling confident as they headed back to New Jersey early Tuesday morning one game below .500 (22-23).  ''The big thing is that we're not going to quit,'' Kidd said after Monday night's game. ''We're going to play hard.''  If nothing else, this trip will be remembered because four of the five games were decided by a point. The Nets were three defensive stops short of having a nine-game winning streak. The Nets became the first team in N.B.A. history to have five of seven games decided by a point and only the fourth team to lose by a point three games in a row, according to the Elias Sports Bureau.  They lost each of the first three games of the trip -- against the Sacramento Kings, the Golden State Warriors and the Los Angeles Clippers -- by a point on their opponent's final shot.  In the fourth game, the Nets played stellar defense against the Denver Nuggets' Carmelo Anthony and Allen Iverson, two of the league's top three scorers. The Nets won that game, 112-102.  On Monday night, the Nets appeared to be out of it when they were down by 2 points with 5.9 seconds left and with the length of the court to go. But Carter jogged the ball up the court, used a screen from center Mikki Moore and drilled the winning shot from about 10 feet beyond the 3-point line.  ''Sometimes, what comes around goes around,'' Nets Coach Lawrence Frank said. ''And I think our guys deserve a great deal of credit for staying together and fighting the fight, so to speak, and not getting discouraged and not wilting and not letting circumstances determine their behavior.''  Perhaps more than anyone else, Carter seemed motivated by the Nets' early struggles on the trip.  Against the Kings, he scored a season-low 8 points and missed two crucial free throws down the stretch. Against the Warriors, he fouled Baron Davis on a 3-pointer late in the game and was later called for charging. Against the Clippers, he left Cuttino Mobley open for the winning 3-pointer.  After each of those games, Carter put much of the blame on himself and appeared uncharacteristically down.  But he made a renewed commitment to attacking the basket. In the final three games of the trip, Carter averaged 35.3 points and shot 66.1 percent from the field. He also averaged 12 free-throw attempts a game, evidence of his aggressiveness in the paint.  ''At the beginning of the trip, each individual had to step their game up, and I felt I had to do the same,'' Carter said Monday night. ''I felt that in the first three games, regardless of points, I didn't deliver because we didn't win the game. I'm just glad I could do it for my team.''  Carter is playing his best at a time when he is the subject of many trade rumors. Although the Nets' president, Rod Thorn, has said that players are worth more in trades when they are playing well, Carter might be making him think twice about any such decision.  The Nets also need Carter more than ever because they are without small forward Richard Jefferson, who missed the trip because of ankle surgery that could keep him out until early March. Jefferson was the Nets' second-leading scorer before he was injured.  Another good sign for the Nets was that their bench helped lift the burden of not having Jefferson. In each game, a different reserve stepped forward.  The rookie Hassan Adams took Jefferson's place in the starting lineup for the first three games, and Wright started the last two. Both were called on for their defense, and they delivered.  Wright was especially impressive. Before starting Saturday night's game against the Nuggets, he had not played in 12 of the previous 19 games. But he scored 11 points and slowed Anthony.  The reserve forward Bostjan Nachbar was averaging 17.7 points over a three-game stretch but became ill before the Jazz game and did not play. So House stepped in with his 19-point effort.  Moore had a fitting description for what these all-around contributions said about the Nets: ''We're a team.''  PRO BASKETBALL
content.title: Nets End 5-Game Trip By Making Their Point

content.text: For one of the few times all game, Wisconsin fans at the Kohl Center turned oddly silent. A Badgers victory that 10 minutes earlier seemed assured was suddenly in peril, and many held their breath as Jamar Butler's 3-point attempt to tie the score descended toward the cylinder in the final seconds.  When the ball clanged off the back rim, and the horn sounded before an Ohio State player could reach it, the third-ranked Badgers had escaped with a 72-69 victory over the No. 5 Buckeyes on Tuesday night. And Butler, who shot from the right wing in front of the Ohio State bench, turned toward his coaches and teammates with a look of disbelief.  ''From my standpoint,'' Ohio State Coach Thad Matta said, ''I'm glad we can check this off on the places we have to go.''  The Badgers (16-1, 2-0 Big Ten) had done what they usually do at Kohl, especially against ranked teams. Led by Kammron Taylor's season-high 25 points, and sparked by the sophomore forward Marcus Landry's 8 points and 4 blocks off the bench in the second half, the Badgers improved to 13-2 against ranked teams here in four seasons under Coach Bo Ryan. Their 85-5 overall mark includes 40-2 in Big Ten play.  A 14-0 run midway through in the second half enabled Wisconsin to take a 16-point lead. After Joe Krabbenhoft's layup began the run, Landry blocked shots by Othello Hunter and Daequan Cook in the same sequence, energizing the crowd. Michael Flowers then stole the ball from Cook and drove for a layup. Ohio State (13-3, 2-1) missed six shots and committed four turnovers before scoring again.  ''We took advantage of some hustle opportunities,'' Ryan said. ''We took advantage of some long rebounds. Sometimes you can get that in transition. When we had the opportunity to run, we did.''  Alando Tucker, the Badgers' leading scorer, had a slow first half, missing 7 of 10 shots and even air-balling a free throw. But he contributed two big baskets in the run. He drove for a layup after Flowers pushed the ball upcourt, and he added a pumping put-back in the lane just before the shot clock expired.  ''I've made a lot of difficult shots,'' Tucker said. ''This is up there with them. It's just determination.''  Wisconsin's defense held Ohio State's two leading scorers, Cook and the 7-foot freshman center Greg Oden, to a combined 15 points, less than half their average. Cook shot 1 for 8 from the field for 5 points. Oden (10 points, 7 rebounds and 6 blocks) had a quiet game until dunking twice in the final 37 seconds.  ''It was an all-around great team effort -- Marcus stepping in, and Joe always does a solid job,'' Tucker said. ''Defensively, we did well almost the whole game. At the end, they hit some shots and it was like, wow.''  That was when things got interesting. Ohio State began fouling with the Badgers ahead by 10 and 1 minute 4 seconds to play. But Wisconsin made 4 of 7 free throws, Ron Lewis hit two 3-pointers, and suddenly Oden's second dunk with eight seconds left made it a 2-point game. Taylor, fouled with seven seconds left, made the first but missed the second, giving Butler his chance.  It had been more than decade since Ohio State played a game in which both teams were ranked in the top five. In 1992, the No. 4 Buckeyes lost to Indiana, which was No. 5. Wisconsin had never played such a game because it had never been ranked higher than sixth before this season.  For the Badgers, this has been a season of uncommon success. Their 15-1 start going into the game matched the best in team history. Wisconsin had already beaten two ranked teams: Marquette and Pittsburgh.  The Buckeyes lost both previous games this season to ranked teams: North Carolina and Florida, the top two teams in the latest A.P. poll.  COLLEGE BASKETBALL
content.title: Wisconsin Defeats Ohio State in a Clash of Top-5 Teams

content.text: The Mets most likely completed their bench for next season by signing the utility player David Newhan yesterday to a one-year contract. Newhan, 33, adds another left-handed bat and provides additional versatility. A natural infielder, Newhan has played 169 of his 229 career games in the outfield and has started at every infield position except shortstop. With Endy Chávez and Ben Johnson projected as the team's fourth and fifth outfielders, Newhan should receive most of his playing time in the infield or as a pinch-hitter.  ''David is a versatile player who can help us in so many spots on the field,'' Mets General Manager Omar Minaya said in a statement. ''We couldn't be more pleased to have him in our organization.''  Newhan batted .252 in 39 games with Baltimore last season and missed four months with a broken fibula. In seven major league seasons with San Diego, Philadelphia and Baltimore, Newhan has hit .256 with 20 home runs and 102 runs batted in. His best season came with Baltimore in 2004, when he hit .311 with 8 homers and 54 R.B.I.  Newhan is the son of Ross Newhan, a former baseball writer for The Los Angeles Times who won the J. G. Taylor Spink Award in 2000 and was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame.  BEN SHPIGEL  BASEBALL
content.title: METS SIGN NEWHAN

content.text: Even though Peyton Manning was not at his best Saturday, the Indianapolis Colts' defense was superb.  Following a script that few expected, the Colts opened the N.F.L. playoffs by defeating the Kansas City Chiefs, 23-8, at the RCA Dome. It was a role reversal for the Colts, known for their high-powered offense led by Manning, and for their porous defense, which ranked last in the league against the run during the regular season.  ''This was playoff football,'' said Colts defensive end Dwight Freeney, who had three tackles and two sacks. ''If not now, then when?''  The Colts changed their identity against the Chiefs. While Manning threw three interceptions in the game and struggled to find his rhythm in the first half, the Colts held Kansas City without a first down until late in the third quarter.  The first seven times that the Chiefs had the ball, they ran three plays and punted. It looked like a scene from the film ''Groundhog Day;'' the same thing happening over and over, as Kansas City's offense produced only seven first downs and 126 total yards.  ''We couldn't run, we couldn't pass, we couldn't do anything,'' Chiefs Coach Herman Edwards said.  When the Chiefs finally made their initial first down, late in the third quarter on a pass from Trent Green to Tony Gonzalez, Colts fans cheered derisively, mocking Kansas City for its struggles. The Chiefs finished that drive by scoring their only touchdown, but that was not enough to save their season, as the Colts advanced to meet the Baltimore Ravens in the next round of the American Football Conference playoffs.  Manning's numbers looked stout (30 for 38, 268 yards, 1 touchdown), but his two first-half interceptions could have changed the game's momentum if his defense had not bailed him out. Manning's first interception should have led to a Chiefs score, and his second probably cost the Colts at least 3 points.  In the third quarter, a pass by Manning was intercepted by Ty Law with no Colts receiver in the vicinity. Usually, it is Manning who confuses the defense, but for much of the game, Kansas City's defensive players kept showing up in places where Manning did not expect them to be.  ''Obviously, those were three poor throws,'' Manning said of his interceptions. ''I told Ty Law I would be glad to introduce him at the Hall of Fame.''  Unfortunately for the Chiefs, their defense eventually wore down. During the first half, Indianapolis had 15 first downs and held the ball for 21 minutes 5 seconds, compared with 8 minutes 55 seconds for Kansas City. Colts running back Joseph Addai took advantage of the tiring defense, rushing for 122 yards on 25 carries and eventually opening up the passing game for Manning.  Leading by 9-0 midway through the third quarter, the Colts scored the game's first touchdown, driving 89 yards in 12 plays to take a 16-0 lead.  How tired was Kansas City's defense? The Colts finished the drive with seven consecutive running plays, moving from Kansas City's 41. Addai capped the drive by running 6 yards up the middle for the touchdown.  Kansas City went to a hurry-up offense and responded with its only scoring drive, moving 60 yards in 8 plays, capped by a 6-yard scoring pass from Green to Gonzalez. Edwards decided to try a 2-point conversion, which paid off, Green passing to Kris Wilson to cut the Colts' lead to 16-8.  But instead of the momentum swinging to the Chiefs, Manning responded with his best drive of the game, moving the Colts 71 yards for their final touchdown, on a 5-yard pass to Reggie Wayne.  It was a satisfying victory for the Colts' defensive players, who had heard talk all week about how they would struggle to stop Chiefs running back Larry Johnson, who rushed for more yards this season than any player except LaDainian Tomlinson of the Chargers. But Johnson was held to 32 yards on 13 carries by the swarming and aggressive Indianapolis defense. By the fourth quarter, the Chiefs were forced to abandon Johnson and try to catch up through the air.  Nothing the Chiefs tried offensively worked for long, as the Colts overcame a lackluster offensive start.  The Colts squandered a chance to put Kansas City into a deep hole early, dominating the statistics but not the scoreboard. The Colts took a 3-0 lead on their opening drive. On their second drive, they looked poised to take a 10-0 lead, with second-and-goal from the 2. But the Chiefs held firm, and when Coach Tony Dungy sent the field-goal unit onto the field, many fans booed. Adam Vinatieri's 19-yarder, his second of three first-half field goals, made the score 6-0.  A brief momentum swing occurred when Law intercepted Manning early in the second quarter after wide receiver Marvin Harrison broke inside and Manning threw outside. Law, who caught the ball near midfield, almost returned it to the end zone after avoiding a tackle attempt by Manning. But he was caught from behind by Harrison at the 9, setting up the Chiefs with first-and-goal.  A touchdown and the extra point would have given Kansas City the lead, and perhaps have changed the direction of the game. Even a field goal would have helped. Instead, the Chiefs got nothing. After two carries by Johnson made it third-and-goal at the 2, Green fell after being accidentally stepped on by one of his lineman as he backed away from center. Kicker Lawrence Tynes compounded the error by missing a 19-yard field goal attempt, hooking the ball against the left upright. Tynes grabbed his head in disbelief, and the Colts ran off the field in celebration.  It was that kind of day for the Chiefs, and a day of redemption for the Colts' defense.  ''This was the way we had hoped to play all year,'' Dungy said. ''We picked a good time to play that way.''  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: A Weakness Is a Strength as the Colts Advance

content.text: After the New England Patriots throttled the Jets on Sunday, 37-16, someone asked Patriots linebacker Tedy Bruschi if the Patriots took their game to another level during the playoffs.  ''The next level to us is the Super Bowl,'' he said. ''And we haven't been there in a while.''  A while? The Patriots won their most recent Super Bowl title two seasons ago. Only one championship has been decided since then, and it went to the Pittsburgh Steelers.  ''That's a while to me,'' Bruschi said.  So it is these days in New England, where a trip to the Super Bowl is a rite of winter. But this winter will be a bit longer for the Patriots if they are to reach their fourth Super Bowl in six seasons. In their three title runs, they did not have to take the long way. The Patriots had first-round byes and needed only two victories, the first at home, to make it to the Super Bowl.  Last season, when the Patriots had to play a first-round game, they beat the Jaguars. The next week, they lost to the Broncos in Denver, 27-13. Of course, the Steelers won the Super Bowl after winning three playoff games on the road.  The Patriots were 12-4 this season, but that earned them only the fourth seeding in the American Football Conference. And their victory over the Jets set up a meeting with the San Diego Chargers, an opponent that no team wants. The Chargers have a 10-game winning streak and are unbeaten at home. The Patriots, as the lowest-seeded team remaining, cannot be the host for the A.F.C. championship game.  The Patriots were 7-1 on the road, with their only loss a 21-0 shocker at Miami.  But none of their previous road opponents had the offensive firepower that the Chargers possess. The game presents excellent matchups. The up-and-coming quarterback Philip Rivers against Tom Brady, the best playoff quarterback in the game. Brady will also go against one of the best pass rushers in the game, Shawne Merriman. Chargers tight end Antonio Gates matches against whatever combination of defenders have to chase him.  The biggest matchup will be the Patriots' front seven, the best in the league, against Chargers running back LaDainian Tomlinson, the N.F.L.'s most valuable player. Tomlinson, who was also named offensive player of the year, rushed for 1,815 yards and 28 touchdowns this season.  ''He's explosive,'' cornerback Asante Samuel said of Tomlinson. ''If you sit back, he'll gas you like he does everyone else.''  Chargers Coach Marty Schottenheimer, who has notably failed in previous postseasons, goes up against Bill Belichick, perhaps the best coach of his era. Still, this is the most balanced team Schottenheimer has ever had, and he has said that Tomlinson is the best running back ever to play in the league. Patriots nose tackle Vince Wilfork called the Chargers ''hands-down the best team in the N.F.L.''  Tomlinson has faced the Patriots only three times since he came into the league in 2001, but he has turned in memorable performances, averaging 141.7 yards. In 2002, he ran for 217 yards and 2 touchdowns. Last season, he had 134 yards and 2 touchdowns as the Chargers scored 24 unanswered points in the second half to win, 41-17. Samuel remembered feeling as if a professional team were playing a college team in that game, with a sense of hopelessness that the Patriots rarely have.  ''He killed us last year,'' Belichick said Monday. ''We're usually looking at the back of his jersey. We haven't done very well against him. He's killed a lot of people besides us, and he's killed us. A team might keep him down for a few carries, but it's just a matter of time before he breaks out, in one way or another, and gets in the end zone.''  The Patriots had the fifth-best run defense in the league this season (they were 12th against the pass and 6th over all), but the perception is that the Patriots lack tremendous speed among their linebackers, a potential liability against Tomlinson. The Jets, who did not have much of a running game, used the speedy Leon Washington to slash through the Patriots' defense. He averaged 4.5 yards while being defended by Bruschi, although he had only 11 carries.  Safety Rodney Harrison, who is critical to holding off a multipronged offensive attack, missed the game against the Jets because of a right knee injury sustained in the regular-season finale against the Titans. On Monday, Belichick said Harrison was day to day and would not say if he would be available Sunday.  In their most successful seasons, the Patriots relied on Harrison in the playoffs to disrupt an explosive offense -- usually that of the Colts and Peyton Manning -- with his hard hits and intensity. Manning and the Colts play the Ravens on Saturday in Baltimore. On Sunday, perhaps without Harrison, New England again faces the most dangerous offensive player, this time in Tomlinson.  PRO FOOTBALL
content.title: Patriots, Hitting the Road, Will Run Into Tomlinson

content.text: Kansas City (9-7) at Indianapolis (12-4)  4:30 p.m., Channel 4  The Colts' offense revolves around quarterback Peyton Manning and receivers Marvin Harrison and Reggie Wayne, and the Chiefs often struggle to stop the pass. Advantage, Colts.  However, the Colts have allowed 173 yards rushing a game, the most in the league, and the Chiefs have a premier runner in Larry Johnson. He carried 416 times (an N.F.L. record) for 1,789 yards and seemed to thrive on heavy duty. Advantage, Chiefs.  Colts Coach Tony Dungy said he was not concerned with how his team closed the regular season, with losses in four of its final seven games.  ''It's kind of like the Indy 500,'' he said. ''You get that starting position and then you run the race. Everyone remembers who won, not who got the pole.''  Reporter's pick: Colts  Dallas (9-7) at Seattle (9-7)  8 p.m., Channel 4  The coaches -- Bill Parcells of the Cowboys and Mike Holmgren of the Seahawks -- have enjoyed playoff success. So have Seattle quarterback Matt Hasselbeck and running back Shaun Alexander, the keys to the Seahawks' offense. Not so Tony Romo, the Cowboys quarterback, and that could be a problem. Dallas's record was 3-3 when the inexperienced Romo replaced Drew Bledsoe. Romo went 5-1 in his first six starts, 1-3 in his last four. He could take advantage of a Seahawks secondary so battered that one starting cornerback is out, the other probably is and three defensive backs were added in recent days. That could also be good news for Terrell Owens, the Cowboys' gifted but talkative receiver.  Reporter's pick: Cowboys  TOMORROW'S MATCHUPS  Jets (10-6) at New England (12-4)  1 p.m., Channel 2  The Jets have won their past three games and beat the Patriots in Week 10, but that was the regular season. For the Patriots, the playoffs are something else. Quarterback Tom Brady's playoff record is 10-1, and he has thrown only 5 interceptions in 11 games. He lacks a go-to receiver, but the Patriots have strong runners in Corey Dillon and Laurence Maroney.  Jets receiver Laveranues Coles said of the Patriots: ''That's the last team you ever want to see in the playoffs because of the way they prepare and the experience they have. I didn't really want to play them in the first round. That's not necessarily a feeling of fear or intimidation. It's more like knowing your opponent a little too well.''  Reporter's pick: Patriots  Giants (8-8) at Philadelphia (10-6)  4:30 p.m., Channel 5  The veteran Jeff Garcia replaced the injured Donovan McNabb (knee) at quarterback and led the Eagles to the National Football Conference East title, Philadelphia's fifth in the past six years. Brian Westbrook, a slick outside runner, also became a force inside as the Eagles won their final five games. ''I believe we are playing our best ball right now,'' safety Brian Dawkins said. The Giants are not; their record is the poorest of the 12 playoff teams. Eli Manning has been inconsistent, Jeremy Shockey is hobbling on a bad ankle, and the defense has its bad days. The one constant has been Tiki Barber, who rushed for a team-record 234 yards last week. He is retiring at 31, so if the Giants lose, this will be his last game.  Reporter's pick: Eagles  PRO FOOTBALL Frank Litsky of The New York Times breaks down the first-round playoff games.
content.title: TODAY'S MATCHUPS
